Nothing this man believes I can agree. I do not intentionally set out to disagree with him or dislike him. But the truth is, I so far always seem to. Developed countries face different issues when dealing with the AIDS epidemic, compared to third world countries. In a country like the US, where people do know about AIDS to varying degrees, problems such as ignorance on basic facts, logistics and distribution of drugs and physical access to medical treatment are probably not as critical. However, whether people know the facts about the disease does not change the fact that the social stigma of being HIV-positive (whether it's developed into full-blown AIDS or not) remains. Social services to HIV-positive patients include giving subsidies for daily expenses such as transportation and child care, providing counselling services, community building and so on. urlLink Kim's execution video banned The government and Internet portal sites said yesterday they would take stern measures against the possible spread on the Internet of the video showing the beheading of the Korean hostage. But still - why should the pictures and video footage be banned? It is a painful but irrefutable fact that he had been killed in a gruesome manner, and there are people out there who need to have a first-hand look at exactly how gruesome it was. A sight that one will not forget, and a visual piece of memory that can motivating one into action. Or at the very least, debate. The way I see it, the ban on the video is likely a measure aiming to prevent anti-government and anti-war sentiments in Korea from escalating any further. Kim's death is a deeply emotional issue. Prior to his death, the country was divided in its decision to deploy its troops to Iraq, and now, I dare say voices supporting the deployment are likely to have been muted at least temporarily while the opposing voices gain extra strength. Kim has become a martyr - against his will, but he has - and the government cannot afford to allow public emotions to run any higher. But shouldn't the media be given the right to censor as per their own discretion? There are humans running these website, newspapers, TV stations - they must know where the balance between human compassion and professional duty lies, it is most irresponsible to place a ban in the name of respect towards the victim's family. On a related (or erm actually not) note, Korea is following China's example of clamping down on blogs on the internet. urlLink See here for an appeal letter by Kevin Kim (via urlLink Pekingduck ).

urlLink US Parties to Allow Bloggers to Cover Party Conventions for First Time More than 15,000 people will converge on Boston later this month to cover the Democratic National Convention -- including, for the first time, bloggers. The Democratic Party plans to give media credentials to a select group of bloggers who want to cover the event, where Sen. John F. It's hardly surprising, however. Especially considering the fact that a blogger is entitled to be biased and partisan unlike journalists, it is time that political parties wake up to the propagandistic power of a blog in their favor. The reverse is also true, of course, that one wrong step can prove disastrous should opposing bloggers pick up on the faux pas, whether the mainstream media does or not. As mentioned briefly in the article, a political blog provides excellent reach to students and youngsters, who generally rely more heavily on the Internet for information. It seems that blogs (with comments enabled) provide a potentially limitless platform for discussion and intellectual interaction for some of these new age netizens. With this year's higher emphasis on the younger voters, parties can probably get their messages out to a larger audience, including those traditionally less interested in politics. Furthermore, I imagine they can also more easily monitor in real time the people's response to them. 'Tis the power of blogs, they say.

urlLink Education on AIDS to Be Compulsory in Beijing AIDS prevention education is set to become mandatory in Beijing, China Daily said on Tuesday. A course for high school students will be taught beginning this autumn semester and has been listed as mandatory. The Beijing Municipal Commission of Education has also decided that primary school students should begin the English language learning as early as the first year in school. The English classes are also scheduled to begin in the autumn semester in September, local authorities said Tuesday. Currently, students in primary schools do not have English classes until the third year. Junior middle schools in the capital city are required to arrange four hours of classes on AIDS prevention on each of the three years of junior secondary education. Although some middle schools have already started AIDS prevention classes, they were not mandatory and educational authorities had not set them as an education requirement, an official with the Beijing Municipal Commission of Education, who asked to be named Tang, said Tuesday. This isn't a new article, it's dated some time in June. I kept it because it's one of those that bothered me though i didn't quite understand why. Then it hit me today. It was this: This is to meet demands for Beijing to host the 2008 Olympic Games and the city's fast development, Tang explained. There is more communication with overseas people in Beijing than other Chinese cities, he pointed out. I had to assume he was referring the language courses, and not the AIDS prevention or narcotics prevention courses. Is it not disturbing, if children were to take these classes only because "hey you'll be talking to foreigners, you'd better know how to speak English and not sound ignorant"? Shouldn't it be more of "hey you'd better know this, this could save your life or someone else's"? It boggles my mind how AIDS and narcotics abuse prevention could be bundled together with foreign language education. If it's indeed that it's for the sake of public image that's got Beijing finally to pay attention to the need for AIDS prevention education, I am disgusted.

urlLink Fear and Ignorance Barriers to China's AIDS Fight China belatedly acknowledged the country's exploding HIV/AIDS problem when Premier Wen Jiabao shook hands with a victim in 2003, but there is still a long way to go before the deadly virus can be countered. It's depressing, reading about the epidemic in China, for the kind of neglect and discrimination victims suffer. Yesterday, an otherwise worldwise friend commented, "Well, but it's not such a bad way to die. At least they had a good time before they..." It's clear her assumption was that most of the victims contracted AIDS from promiscuity, and thereby "had a good time" before they had to suffer the consequences. I was angry! Furious beyond words, that she could even make such an assumption. Though she quickly qualified her statement, "Well, excluding those who got it from intravenous injections and so on," the damage had been done. Is this the kind of stigma we have to counter? If an educated Singaporean executive can think this way, what about the average illiterate Chinese farmer?

urlLink Dr Jiang Yanyong released Jiang Yanyong, the military doctor who exposed China's SARS cover-up last year, has been released after seven weeks in custody during which he underwent "study sessions", family members say. I cannot claim to understand. Honestly. Of what the government wanted of him. He was taken in for the letter he wrote to the leaders of the CCP requesting a reappraisal of their actions in the Tiananmen incident, which in itself could have angered them, but would not have warranted such a drastic action, especially since he has been a loyal member of the party, and is not in any position to challenge their authority. It would have taken only some vague reply to the letter, to temporarily shut him up, if not pacify him. In contrast with the SARS cover-up, a retrospective reappraisal does not inspire the same urgency for change and action. The problem arose only from the leakage of the letter to the media. Given Dr Jiang's status as a widely respected hero among the Chinese, the government is right to fear the possible public unrest inspired by his letter. Yet, since the letter had indeed already been leaked, and is obviously already out of his hands, what good does it do to take him in, only to cause only a more serious uproar for the obvious act of oppression of the beloved doctor? The fact that he was put through "study sessions" or put more bluntly, brainwashing sessions suggests that the officials had wanted to change his mind, perhaps of the Tiananmen incident, perhaps of something of a bigger scale, who knows. But why do they think they would be able to effect that change? He is an old man with a mind of his own, and a fearless passion for his country. He must respect the authorities to a certain aspect, to have chosen to go through the official channel of writing a letter requesting for the reassessment, rather than work his popularity to his advantage. urlLink How USD15 billion should (not) be spent The U.S. global AIDS plan stipulates that by 2006 one-third of the money spent on HIV prevention must be used for "abstinence until marriage" programs, about 7 percent of the $15 billion budget. An analysis of grants awarded under the plan, conducted by a Maryland-based organization monitoring U.S. international health policy, found that a large amount of the prevention money is being used in programs to prevent infected mothers from passing HIV to their babies. This mode of transmission accounts for only 5 percent of new infections in Africa, the region primarily targeted by the Bush plan. Jodi L. Jacobson, executive director of the Maryland-based Center for Health and Equity, which conducted the analysis, said that relatively little money is going to prevent HIV transmission through heterosexual intercourse, which accounts for about 80 percent of infections in Africa. When the organization studied grants to programs directed at that risk group, "between 60 and 80 percent of all money is going to abstinence-only programs," she said. The US global AIDS coordinator defended the policy: On the topic of sexual abstinence, which has been strongly debated during the conference, he said the administration's approach was fair and focused on "A-B-C," or "Abstinence" and "Be Faithful" and "Condom Use," in that order. "Abstinence works. Being faithful works. Condoms work," he said. "Each has its place." which is contradictory, is it not? A-B-C, "in that order," then that "each has its place?" If they each have its place, why the priority on abstinence? As far as prevention measures go, how does abstinence help married women in countries where they do not necessarily have the right to refuse their husbands' advances? How does that help the prostitutes who (as sad it sounds) cannot feed themselves and their families without selling their bodies? And don't even get me started on the other primary mode of transmission - tainted needles. But anyway this only makes me even more curious as to how they are spending the USD 15 billion. 7% or USD 1.05 billion may sound like a lot to spend on abstinence programs, and I do not agree with it. But if allowing it is what it takes to get the other USD 13.95 billion out there, so be it.

urlLink Taming the multiverse Parallel universes are no longer a figment of our imagination. They're so real that we can reach out and touch them, and even use them to change our world, says Marcus Chown. [...] But how is it that atoms can be in many places at once whereas big things made out of atoms-tables, trees and pencils-apparently cannot? Reconciling the difference between the microscopic and the macroscopic is the central problem in quantum theory. The many worlds interpretation is one way to do it. This idea was proposed by Princeton graduate student Hugh Everett III in 1957. According to many worlds, quantum theory doesn't just apply to atoms, says Deutsch. "The world of tables is exactly the same as the world of atoms." But surely this means tables can be in many places at once. Right. But nobody has ever seen such a schizophrenic table. So what gives? The idea is that if you observe a table that is in two places at once, there are also two versions of you-one that sees the table in one place and one that sees it in another place. I did a search for the article, because I happened to mention this to a friend. I brought it up in arguing that the fact that money has been granted does not necessary mean that the money can be spent in the most effective manner, because the US has required that urlLink all drugs bought with the fund must be FDA approved . Specified in the giant President's Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, the restrictions against unapproved generics, which for now include all foreign-made generics, have added to the already long list of obstacles to bringing antiretroviral (ARV) therapy to poor countries, experts attending the 15th International AIDS Conference here say. "It was very confusing. You're trying to figure out who can buy what with what money," said Joia Mukherjee, medical director for Partners in Health, a Boston-based organization that has run an AIDS treatment program in Haiti for seven years and is developing others in Latin America. The policy "slows the coordination" between the Bush plan and the people running treatment programs in the countries, Mukherjee said in an interview at the conference. In defence of the plan, my friend argued, "But it is fair that they would like to ensure that the drugs are reliable and effective medication." I find that very unconvincing. FDA is but a US agency. Suggesting that Americans live by higher standards would be rather presumptuous though probably not untrue. Still, I do not believe that FDA's standards and requirements should have to apply for citizens of the world. It reeks of condescending arrogance again, in the 'our way is the best way, and we are only trying to protect you' kind of way. In any case, Then what about what the WHO does? It's at least neutral and internationally accepted. Most organizations that are providing money for AIDS drugs in those countries -- notably, the two-year-old Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria -- require that generics they purchase go through a process called pre-qualification that is run by the World Health Organization and is similar to FDA approval. Whatever the rationale behind this requirement (I am fairly certain the fair bit of political pressure from the pharmaceutical giants in the US must have played a role in this), the result is the same - there is money, but it cannot be used to purchase cheap generics because they have not been FDA approved. This is not an insurmountable obstacle - sure, go ahead and get these drugs approved then. But it's frustrating, in a desperate and pressing race against time, against AIDS.

A common charge against US occupation of Iraq, was that it was a thinly veiled conspiracy for generating wealth for US companies. Exactly how much of Iraqi reconstruction funds are used to grant contracts to US firms had never been known, urlLink till now. For the first 14 months of the occupation, officials of the Coalition Provisional Authority provided little detailed information about the Iraqi money, from oil sales and other sources, that it spent on reconstruction contracts. They have said that it was used for the benefit of the Iraqi people and that most of the contracts paid from Iraqi money went to Iraqi companies. But the CPA never released information about specific contracts and the identities of companies that won them, citing security concerns, so it has been impossible to know whether these promises were kept. The CPA has said it has awarded about 2,000 contracts with Iraqi money. Its inspector general compiled records for the major contracts, which it defined as those worth $5 million or more each. Analysis of those and other records shows that 19 of 37 major contracts funded by Iraqi money went to U.S. companies and at least 85 percent of the total $2.26 billion was obligated to U.S. companies. The contracts that went to U.S. firms may be worth several hundred million more once the work is completed. (my emphasis.) Which means about at least USD 1.9 billion of funds go to US companies. The article is long, but sheds light on issues with authorization of funds used, with Iraqi representation in deciding how the contracts are granted, and with commingling of US and Iraqi money to pay for tasks under a single contract.
